I do hope this helps.  It's a huge decision and I wish you all the best in making the right choice for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2008 07:28AM Nichola wrote: Just thought I'd offer my experience.  I don't have skin "mets", but I do/did have a skin recurrence in my reconstruction...ie. localised to the breast area... I had 3 x malignant satellite nodules in the skin that presented as follows:- 1.  Directly over one of my removed tumour sites:-  A raides nodule..with skin thickening that looked like a raised bruise. 2.  A raid nodule and skin thickening, whitish n middle...on scar line. 3.  An area of skin thickening with broken blood vessels about 2" from tumour site. I had to have my reconstruction removed and radiotherapy. Hope this helps! Nikki

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 04:10PM - edited May 6, 2009 04:13PM by Nichola Hi Cabarette I'm more than hopeful if not sure you have nothing to worry about, but I respect that even as a teenager,  when the likelyhood is so small if you feel so uncertain you should indulge your worries and get answers.  I truly believe that intuition should be acted on and as Leaf points out perhaps you  would benefit from expert advice.  It is unusual for a girl of your age (you don't say how old?)  to be even checking your breasts, perhaps you are on to something or perhaps you need to discover why such things are crossing your mind?  I am curious, do you have a family member or friend that has had BC?  To be that worried that you submit to a forum has to have some significance that needs to be shared and sorted. Whatever your age BC does happen as I have experienced with very young friends and witnessed on this very site.  I commend your vigilence and advise that you have a right to know what exactly the lumps you have are?  You need assurances and hopefully, from those assurances you can get on with your life. I commend you for sharing and asking advice.  It shows a maturity that you mum, when you speak to her (as you must) should be very proud of. Love, hugs and good luck Nikkix

Posts.Content: Nichola wrote: Onc confirmed the 2.5cm x 2cm lump in my "good"  boob that I have been in denial about.  Urgent referral for US/biopsy is on Tuesday, but I now realise that I have a second lump close by.  I have been working so hard on trying to get on with my life and am scheduled for revision surgery (Diep) and uplift of this breast in July after losing my first LD reconstruction due to a recurrence in the skin. Psychologically this surgery was to be my "closure".  Now I've found the second lump, the waves of anxiety are overwhelming.  I'm OK and putting on a brave face for hubby etc., during the day, but the nights are are horrendous. I'm thinking that even if they are benign they will want to remove them because of my history and the fact they seem to be growing fast...?  I had multi-focal the first time and had to have a mastectomy.  Has anyone out there kept their breast with multi-focal? Any support will be truly appreciated. Nikkix  Original DX Stage 1, Grade 1 multifocal IDC 2004. Multiple nodule recurrence in skin of reconstruction, Nov 2007 and reconstruction removed. I am so relieved it's untrue!   I know I'm not completely out of the woods, but I am feeling really positive so for now I am happy! Love to you all... Nikkix
Posts.Title: 3rd time? Just found 2nd lump... Nichola Nichola

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 11:36AM - edited Mar 30, 2009 11:41AM by Nichola Hi Aspen At your age it is not unusual for your breasts to get lumps:  They can be anything from hormonal lumps that disappear after a month to fibroidanomas to cysts and far less likely to be BC!  However, whatever the lump, if it's there after 3 or 4 weeks, you need to get it checked and I agree with the other girls...get it biopsied if there is ANY uncertainty.  The problem with just mammos or ultrasound is that until we reach menopause our breasts are very dense and imagery is hard to decipher. I hope you have spoken to a gyno about your lack of periods...?   You may well have common ovarian cysts which are better monitored. Best of luck Nikki x

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2008 09:38AM - edited Jun 22, 2008 09:39AM by Nichola My advice is that "any" changes in breast size, shape etc... should be checked, but certainly this is not a definitive symptom of BC.  Get to that breast clinic and hopefully put your mind at rest... there on...keep vigilant!

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 11:29AM - edited May 13, 2008 11:30AM by Nichola I do feel for you....especially after what happened to your mum: My advice is get back in touch with the radiologist and ask them to explain more fully what they saw and why they think it's OK to wait 6 months? And/OR...if you decide to go for a second opinion you have to request the films of your MRI and any notes and tell them you want to put your mind at rest by getting a second opinion.  They are completely used to this and won't be offended and can suggest where you could go.  (They will have to see you in person).  Do you have a John Hopkins Clinic near you)? Do let us know how you get on... Sending you love and luck...

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 05:03PM Nichola wrote: Hi Tamsha 5 years has always been a benchmark for BC sufferers.  Before the improvement in treatments 5 years NED (No Evidence of Desease), was considered to have a great prognosis as recurrence is much more likely to happen within that time.  Also, when scientist do their research, they often relate to studies that look at women in 1 year, 5 years and 10 years to report overall survival or recurrence rates! Good luck Nikki

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2009 02:30PM Nichola wrote: Hi Susan From my humble experience you have had a sentinel node removal which is the latest, less invasive lymph surgery:  The sentinel node is the "watchdog" node, nearest to the breast.   Surgeons nowadays feel that removal and pathology of this node has less SEs and by itself is an indicater of a cancer on the move.  Some surgeons still remove several axillary nodes, some rely on taking out just this one which can reduce your chances of lymphodema. Hope this helps, Best of luck and sorry for your DX. Nikkix
